The changing energy-chemistry nexus is discussed in this perspective paper about the future of sustainable energy and chemical production to identify the priorities and open issues on which focus research and development. Topics discussed regard (i) the new sustainable energy scenario, (ii) the role of energy storage (from smart grids to chemical storage of energy), (iii) the outlooks and role of solar (bio)refineries and solar fuels, (iv) how to integrate bio- and solar-refineries to move to new economy, (v) the role of methanol at the crossover of new energy-chemistry nexus, (vi) the role of chemistry in this new scenario, (vii) the role of nanomaterials for a sustainable energy, (viii) the use of nanocarbons to design advanced energy conversion and storage devices, and (ix) possibilities and routes to exploit solar energy and methane (shale gas). The contribution provides a glimpse of the emerging directions and routes with some elements about their possible role in the future scenario, but does not provide a detailed analysis of the state of the art in these directions. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Energy Chemistry Future scenario Catalysis Sustainability 1 Introduction Energy and chemistry are at the core of our current society [1,2], but the nexus between them has not been often discussed specifically, neither how it is evolving in parallel to the changing scenario for a sustainable energy and chemistry. An analysis of these aspects and of the underlying vision for the future in this area (from a sustainability perspective) is necessary to identify new directions of research and opportunities for competiveness. We are in fact likely at the beginning of a transition to a new economy and production system. The evolution of industrial production is not linear, but shows a cyclic evolution [3]. In chemistry and energy production, most of the technologies and processes were developed over a half century ago, and are at the stage of maturity now. But new technologies, focused on the use of renewable resources and energy, are emerging and will constitute the backbone of the future economic cycle [3]. The transition to this new cycle, which is driven from the combined availability of new raw materials and technologies together with novel social demands, is quite fast, as shown for example about 60 years ago after the introduction of chemical processes based on olefins and of new refinery processes. It is thus necessary, from an industrial perspective, to understand and anticipate this transition, to maintain competiveness. A key element is to examine the changing energy-chemistry nexus to identify the priorities and open issues on which focus research and development. This perspective contribution, opening the change in editorial direction of Journal of Energy Chemistry (JEC), will address these issues to provide a basis for discussion on the strategic elements around which the journal aims to growth. It is indicated as vision, because it is mainly based on a thought and concept of the future model of sustainable energy and chemical production. Different opinions may exist on these aspects, but it is not the aim to discuss in depth them here, and analyze pro/cons of the various ideas. There is a general agreement that the use of alternative “green/sustainable and renewable” resources is at the core of this transition to a new economic cycle [4], even if fossil fuels are and will be still for at least the next two-three decades available at relatively low costs. However, it is an error to consider that for this reason there is no need to change the current energy and chemistry economy. It is the push to innovation and competiveness, combined with other driving factors (socio-environmental motivations, greenhouse gas–GHG–education, resource security and related motivations, creating new value chains and other aspects) that will determine the change. Enable the transition requires to insert the new technologies/processes within the current economic and productive infrastructure, in order to reduce the investments that otherwise will be too large. Drop-in products or processes, e.g. those inserting within the current energy-chemistry system largely depending on the use of fossil-fuels, are thus necessary. However, it is essential to change the current energy-chemistry nexus. Chemistry should provide new solutions, from materials to energy conversion and storage, to develop a more sustainable use of energy [1]. A closer integration between energy and chemistry is needed in many areas, to develop new effective models of biorefineries for example [5]. It is necessary to overcome through chemistry the use of energy mainly as thermal energy, including in chemical processes, with related thermodynamic limitations and exploit potentially more efficient routes such as the direct use of electrons and photons [5c]. In other words, it should be realize an energy intensification to parallel the more known concept of process intensification. A larger integration of solar energy within the energy-chemistry value chain going beyond the use of only photovoltaic cells is a compulsory step, requiring the development of new advanced energy materials. But extending the use to other renewable energy (RE) sources, from geothermy to wind energy, hydropower, etc., is another relevant element, which implementation requires also often chemistry solutions, for example to store and transport to long distance RE through suitable chemical energy vectors. An effective transition to a sustainable energy and chemistry future requires extending also the use of alternative fossil fuels, creating the new chemistry and processes for their clean utilization [5]. The future of chemistry will be likely based on an extended use of new raw materials going beyond the current oil-centric vision [5d]. These and other aspects are changing the energy-chemistry nexus and the future of sustainable energy and chemical production. They are core topics of JEC which aims to become a forum of discussion of these changes, the future scenario for energy chemistry and the related science and technology developments. 2 Moving to a new sustainable energy scenario In order to progress toward a sustainable energy production and use it is imperative to increase progressively the use of renewable (regenerative) energy (solar, wind, hydro, etc.), and in the transitory to increase the smarter use of biomass (e.g. use of biomass in more eco-efficient processes than simple combustion) [4,6]. In fact, on a LCA (life cycle analysis) basis [7,8] (Table 1), electrical energy generated from coal has an estimated impact about twice (in terms of grams of CO2 equivalent per kWh) than that of natural gas (but value for shale gas is higher), while RE sources (biomass, wind, solar photovoltaic-PV, hydro, etc.) have on the average an impact ten times lower than that of coal. The impact of extra-heavy crude, tar sands, shale oil is similar to coal, in some cases even worse on a LCA basis. There is also a proportional decrease in the emissions of pollutants such as NO x and SO x , and particulate matter as well. While it may be long discussed on the absolute values of these different energy technologies (recent technology development for PV cells for example, issues in biomass utilization-land change use for example, etc. have to be better considered), the trend is clear and demonstrated the need of moving to a new vision of production and use of energy, to contrast the natural trend in the expansion of demand related to the increasing population accessing to a large fruition of energy. Despite the international economic crisis and other issues, the global demand for RE continued to rise during last years. Renewable power generation continued to grow strongly, reaching almost 22% of the global mix in 2013, compared with 21% in 2012 and 18% in 2007 [9a]. Globally, renewable electricity generation is now on par with that of natural gas, which remained relatively stable in last years. Globally, wind power accounted for about 40% of renewable power capacity added recently, followed by hydropower and solar PV, each accounting for approximately 26% [10]. However, hydropower remains still the largest contribution to modern renewables. In year 2013, it accounted for nearly 75% of world renewable electricity generation (about 5 PWh) and estimations for year 2017 indicate still about 70% of about 6.4 PWh produced of worldwide renewable electricity [9]. It is interesting to observe that the expansion in the use of RE sources is larger than that expected from agencies such as IEA (International Energy Agency) about 10–15 years ago. For example, IEA predicted in its World Energy Outlook 2000 that non-hydro RE would comprise 3% of global energy by 2020. That benchmark was reached in 2008. This is due to an underestimation of the (i) capability of technology development, (ii) lowering in the costs of production (PV cells, wind powered devices, for example), (iii) governmental push in some countries, Germany for example, and (iv) other important factors. Between these, the investment costs. A distributed energy production such as the case of PV cells or wind powered devices requires relatively small investments per unit with respect to centralized systems (power plants, etc.) which find also an increasing social opposition. Although many units are necessary to reach the same capacity of a centralized unit, there are many more investors interested in the investment, differently from centralized units for which a quasi-monopoly system exists. As a consequence, when supported from governmental incentives, the rate of introduction of RE was faster than supposed. Clearly, a distributed energy generation system requires having an adequate grid system able to accept and distribute this RE to users. This is an element which development has not proceeded in parallel with the expansion of PV installations, and is now one of the critical bottlenecks for further expansion. A critical factor is also the decoupling between demand, research development and production. While Europe contributed to about 60% of the total cumulated PV installations in 2013, in contrast to China and Taiwan accounting for 13% of the total cumulated installations, the latter have a market share of about 70% of the worldwide shipments, with over 90% of the production based on old technologies (single or multi-crystalline modules) [9b]. A similar observation could be made on the difference between research intensity market shares. In addition, the predictions about the change in technology of PV cells also failed. While large advances in efficiencies have been made from technological sides (with peak efficiencies over 46% in multi-junction cells), the largest part of the market is still dominated from the first generation (silicon-based) cells and the change to more efficient cells is slower than initially forecasted [10]. IEA observed the decoupling between efficiency and marked perspectives [9b]. The lowest PV costs are not necessarily achieved with the highest efficiencies, and small improvements in efficiency can come at too high a cost to be worthwhile. Record cell efficiencies achieved on very small surface areas do not immediately translate into affordable commercial high-efficiency modules. Several PV-producing companies get in crisis having assumed a faster introduction of new generation PV cells. The market in RE has a dynamic partly decoupled from the advances in nanotechnology, because efficiency considerations have been predominant over cost-efficiency ones, a lesson that should be further considered in analyzing the priorities for the future. The actual limit in advanced countries to the further expansion in the production and use of RE is the passage to a smart grid system [11]. In fact, RE sources such as wind and solar produce electrical energy in a discontinuous and fluctuating way (over the day and the year), which matches only in part the fluctuating energy demand. This causes destabilization of the electric grids with potential blackouts, weakening voltage and damage to industrial equipment [12]. Smart grids [11] incorporate in principle different technologies for energy storage, from novel advanced batteries (including flow batteries) to traditional systems such as pumped hydro and compressed air energy storage. These storage devices are characterized from different energy storage capacity, power output and discharge time to balance the mismatch between supply and demand, but there are critical aspects regarding the long-term storage and long-distance distribution. Today a significant fraction of the potential RE (by wind, in particular) is lost because cannot be introduced in the grid. These aspects will be discussed in a more detail in the next section, because it is necessary to introduce shortly before other elements. Different energy scenarios have been proposed in literature, for example by Shaahid et al. [13], Cosmi et al. [14], da Silva et al. [15], Ghahadan and Koomey [16]. These approaches rarely start from the analysis of the technological possibilities and constrains, having thus limits in the predictions. On the other hand, the analysis of the possible energy scenarios [6] is a key element to identify how de-bottlenecking the system to accelerate the introduction of sustainable energy as well as to recognize earlier the possible “game changer” technologies. An important element to consider in this analysis, although often missing, is that it is necessary to guarantee a smooth transition to the new energy system. The use of biomass and non-conventional fossil fuels plays a relevant role from this perspective [1,4,6]. However, there are other relevant elements not always recognized, such as how to trade, distribute and store RE on a world scale, as currently occurs with oil and derivate energy vectors. This objective cannot be reached even with long distance smart grids, but can be realized by chemical energy storage, particularly in the form of liquid fuels. The relevance of these aspects becomes critical, when substitution of the use of fossil fuels by RE sources becomes higher than about 40%. There are various countries aiming to higher targets within few years Denmark has the target to arrive within 2050 to the complete elimination of importing fossil fuels, using a mix of RE produced mainly by wind and biogas. Germany is also planning to get 80% of its energy from RE by 2050. Other countries in Europe will also move in this direction, although with a slower speed. Other countries in the word have instead different targets: (i) to become net energy exporter based on oil and gas (shale gas) own resources (US), (ii) to exploit own biomass (Brazil, Argentina) or (iii) coal (China) resources. In general, there are different regional scenarios to pass from an oil-centric vision (based on an extensive energy trading) to a future where the exploitation of own resources will be a dominant factor. Energy cost and security are driving elements to proceed in this direction, but it is clear that when fossil fuels or biomass resources are not sufficient to supply the regional demand, RE and in particular solar energy are the necessary pushing factors to proceed along energy independency. If the irradiance on only 1% of the Earth's surface could be converted into electric energy with 10% efficiency, it would provide a resource base of 105 TW, e.g. ten times the estimated world energy increase by year 2050. The use of solar irradiation is thus a necessary factor to meet a RE scenario and energy independency. This target requires developing in a synergetic way different technologies, from energy generation to conversion and storage. Energy is need for different purpose, from mobility to industrial and residential use. There are different requirements in terms of energy density for these applications that should be considered in looking at the energy scenario. We may comment that the chemical storage of energy (in the form of liquid fuels) will remain a technology outperforming the energy density in batteries, even considering the possible future developments in terms of energy materials [17–19]. Liquid fuels will remain in the future, in our opinion, an essential component for mobility requiring high energy density vectors. These liquid fuels could derive from different sources, biomass or solar fuels (see later). 3 Energy storage: from smart grids to chemical storage of energy Energy needs to be stored to match demand, as introduced before. Smart grids use a combination of different devices and regulatory tools [20] to meet this goal requiring to create a hierarchy of storage solutions which different in terms of energy storage capacity and time. Although a single definition of smart grid does not exist, it is commonly accepted that comprises a broad range of technology solutions that optimize the energy value chain [21]. There are various key elements in a smart grid: (i) distributed and centralized energy production systems, (ii) storage systems with different time of operation and power to compensate positive and negative fluctuations in the energy consumption and demand, (iii) a grid to distribute the energy and a management system to control all. A smart grid is a necessary next-step for the future energy infrastructure and will be the backbone of the future decarbonized power system. Energy storage devices are the key element, which allow the implementation of this vision, but still many challenges exist to raise the performances of these devices (batteries, for example) to the requested performances. The extension of smart grid concept is a general intelligent system able to optimize the energy production and use at a regional/country level and which extends beyond the electrical grid by including the natural gas network, etc. A part of this vision is related to the development of technologies and device which enable trading of energy at a long distance, e.g. > of about 500–1000 km. Transport of electrical energy requires a grid, and it is not efficient over long distances. Conversion of electrical to chemical energy allows a better and more efficient transport at long distance, and the storage of energy for rather long times. In terms of smart grid, this solution enables also to import (and trade on world scale) the RE produced in remote areas. This is a key aspect missed to how limit their vision to extended smart grids. In fact, the transition to a new sustainable energy system requires to implement an energy system at least equivalent in functionality to that actually present. This is largely oil-centric for one specific reason: the easy possibility of storage and transport to long distance of oil and derivate energy vectors. Natural gas is cleaner than oil, but being a gas has technical limits in storage and in the transport out of a grid. Coal is a cheaper fossil fuel than oil in several countries, although has a higher environmental impact as shown also in Table 1. In addition, the transport of coal and storage in open air creates additional problems related to dust emissions. For this reason, conversion to liquid fuels or chemical (methanol, for example, as discussed later) is an effective and clean option for its larger use. The world scale implementation of a sustainable energy system based on RE demands to develop RE vectors equivalent to those actually in use, e.g. with high energy density, relatively safe in use, easy to transport and store. This is the main motivation to develop liquid solar fuels. To note that often H2 is indicated as solar fuel, but does not has the characteristics indicated above. Methane produced from CO2 reduction is also indicated as solar fuel, when produced for example from excess wind electrical energy (power to gas process). However, also this fuel fails to have the characteristics indicated above, even if may be find use in some energy storage situations (it is actually largely push in Germany). It should be also remarked that there is a large untapped hydropower potential. The global technically exploitable hydropower potential is estimated at more than 16.4 PWh per year, e.g. over 80% of the potential is still unexploited [22]. A large part of this potential can be utilized only when effective ways to transport this RE to long-distances (>500 km) are developed. This solution offers the great opportunity to combine a cost-effective increase in generation capacity to the diversification of energy sources and thus better energy security. Deserts and arid regions offer also a large, unexploited potential for large-scale generation of RE (PV, wind), which can be effectively exploited only when the transport to long-distance of the produced electrical energy is solved. The cost of production of electrical energy by wind and by solar photovoltaic (PV) panels is rapidly falling and in desert/arid areas, where density of population and fauna is limited, the impact on land and environment is reduced. Finally, the conversion of electrical to chemical energy, by synthetizing liquid energy vectors such as methanol, allows solving the issue of intermittency in energy generation by wind and solar PV panels. The potential of wind and solar energy production costing less than 50€/MWh (in 2050) was estimated to be over 10 PWh [23]. Assuming that only a fraction of this potential RE can be exploited, there is still a potential of over 10 PWh/year of electrical energy which can be produced from unexploited renewable sources and which use can be enabled from the development of effective technologies to store and transport the RE using suitable energy vectors. These should well integrate within the actual energy (and chemical) production chain to avoid the costs and time related to changing the actual infrastructure. In addition, electrical energy accounts for about one third of global consumption of energy today, while RE sources produce mainly electrical energy as output. Converting electrical to chemical energy by producing suitable energy vectors allows a more flexible use of energy in different applications (transport, residential, industry, etc.). Suitable energy vectors can be used also as base raw materials for the chemistry sector enabling a new low-carbon economy [24]. It is thus reasonable the estimation that within the next two decades about 10 PWh/year of additional RE could be exploited by enabling an effective route for electrical to chemical energy conversion to store and transport RE, and by integrating this possibility into an extended smart grid.
