The suffix Tera indicates 1012, while the suffix Peta indicates 1018. Enabling the trading of RE through the use of CO2 may be thus a game changer for the future sustainability of energy use, with relevant implications also on the smart grids, because part of the issue related to grid instability due to the discontinuous production of RE by solar panels and wind-powered devices are solved by a larger use of the conversion of electrical to chemical energy. 4 Toward solar (bio)refineries and solar fuels Chemical storage of energy will have an increasing role in the future of sustainable energy production and use [25], as discussed in the previous section. Solar fuels indicate generically those energy vectors which are produced using RE (not only limited to solar direct use) and thus utilized to store and transport RE [26]. Solar (bio)refineries [27] are a key part of this vision. Fig. 1 illustrates briefly the concept of solar (bio)refineries and the integration with the energy infrastructure. The flow chart of key components of a “solar (bio)refinery” indicates how hydrogen generation options can be combined with molecular precursors to form a couple of platform molecules. These can be further converted into useful classes of energy carriers in a similar way as that present today in refineries. Fig. 1 evidences the systemic character of chemical energy storage, the integration with biomass use, the need of a tight integration between fuels and chemicals production, and the interrelation with the energy systems. In other words, the energy-chemistry nexus introduced before. Enabling this vision for the future of a sustainable energy system requires to progress in many important scientific areas, some of them will be discussed later. The solar (bio)refinery provides a framework concept for chemical energy storage and integration of RE within bio-economy. Some of the elements will be integrated in the future to single devices (artificial leaf-like) [28], which lump together the different steps necessary today. For example: - a first step of generation of electrical energy (ee) (wind, hydro, solar photovoltaic-PV or thermal-CSP e.g. concentrated solar power, one method of solar thermal energy harvesting); - a second step of generation of H2 by water electrolysis (this can be at low temperature using PEM-polymer electrolyte membrane cells, or high temperature SOEC-solid oxide electrolyzer cell); - a third step of use of this renewable H2 (eventually after compression) in combination with CO2 to synthetize platform molecules that can be eventually further converted to drop-in refinery products or chemicals. The use of biomass well integrates into this vision, and the CO2 produced (each ton of bioethanol produced forms about one ton of high purity CO2) could be used as CO2 source [29]. The availability of large amounts of clean water is pre-requisite, a resource that may be scarce in future times. The solar refinery concept is based on the idea that the produced solar fuels are integrated within the existing infrastructure and technologies, but in perspective novel energy vectors can be introduced with better application characteristics than the pool of hydrocarbons derived from oil. In a long-term strategy, the function of charge separation and chemical conversion of storage molecules water and CO2 may be combined in single processes referred to as “artificial leaf” strategies [28]. Despite the impressive progress in these areas, still about two decades will be necessary to develop such systems to dimensions delivering grid-relevant amounts of energy. However, some aspects of the integration of bio- and solar-refineries [5] can be realized in a short term to provide an effective path for the transition to the new low-carbon and sustainable economy. 5 Integrating bio- and solar-refineries to move to new economy Lowering the impact on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, in addition to other motivations (energy security, promote rural living, etc.) is a major motivation for regulations and incentives for biofuel utilization. The possibility to further expand the use of biomass to move to a new (bio)economy is necessary to make a step forward in reducing GHG and environmental impact. Being large amounts of CO2 produced in fermentation processes [29], one of the key elements in biofuel production, the integration of renewable (solar) energy and CO2 reuse within biorefinery cycle is a crucial step forward. In fact, the transformation of CO2 to fuels allows to incorporate RE in the chemical energy of the fuel (or chemical), providing the more functional way to introduce RE into the energy and chemical value chain, while the direct use of electrical energy (the main actual output of RE sources) is not very effective for many constrains [24]. In addition, the conversion of CO2 using RE may also produce raw materials for chemistry, evidencing the nexus between energy-chemistry to move to a new low-carbon economy. Zhang [30a] remarked how the next generation biorefineries based on artificial photosynthesis could produce large amount chemicals from H2/electricity and CO2. Carbon dioxide utilization in integrated biorefineries was also discussed in detail by Sharifzadeh et al. [30b] . As an indication of the possible impact of integration of CO2 (re)use within a biorefinery scheme, it is possible to consider the integration of renewable methanol production within a second generation bioethanol production plant [31]. The CO2 produced from biological fermentation is send to a methanol synthesis unit, fed with hydrogen produced by electrolysis. The oxygen produced from the electrolysis, together with the heat deriving from the exothermic methanol synthesis unit is utilized in the biomass pretreatment unit (before the biological fermentation). Heat recovery from these units is used for the fermentation stage. The heat produced in the electrolysis may be recovered as well. This combined production of bioethanol and renewable methanol allows increasing the energy efficiency from about 66% to up to over 80%–85% (in preliminary estimations), with a parallel increase in the carbon efficiency of biomass utilization, e.g. a significant decrease of the carbon footprint of the process and of biofuels use [31]. This is well in agreement with Sharifzadeh et al. [30b] indications of the possibility to increase biomass to fuel conversion from 55% to 73%, when CO2 utilization is integrated in biorefinery. This scheme of integration, however, requires some technology development. It is necessary, for example, to use either novel low-temperature biomass treatments (operating below about 60–70 °C, for example using ionic liquids) or high-temperature electrolyzer (solid oxide electrolyzers, temperature of operations >600 °C) instead that the more conventional PEM-type electrolyzers operating at around 80 °C. However, it is evident that this is an interesting direction to progress to a more efficient use of bioethanol process. There are other main options to integrate solar (renewable) energy within a bio-refinery/-factory scheme: (i) Use of this energy to produce chemicals (or intermediates needed to produce the final chemicals, such as H2), either locally (in particular, exploiting the electrical energy which is in excess to that which can be introduced to the grid), or remote, where unexploited resources can be utilized. (ii) Use of light-active micro-organisms. Regarding the second option, there are two types of possibilities. The first regards synthetic enzymatic pathways for CO2 utilization powered by electricity, as proposed for example by Zhang et al. [32] and the second regards the use of microalgae [33]. The use of microalgae is still under active discussion regarding whether or not may be economically sustainable, but may be noted that large scale microalgae cultivations (in open ponds) are already in operations by many companies [33] and many R&D projects are running on large scale worldwide from years. Cost of production in open ponds, especially using seawater or wastewater, is lower than the cost to produce an equivalent biomass (on oil bases) [33]. High harvesting and downstream processing costs are aspects significantly improved recently [34]. New technologies of oil recovery avoid the need to concentrate from around 5% to over 99% the algae slurry to recover the algal oil. These technologies decrease largely energy and costs in algae downstream processing. By combining these advances with the full utilization of microalgae biomass, positive economics are possible, especially when the process is integrated with a specific value chain. Therefore, even if issues to solve still remain, there are many indications [33–39] about the sustainability of micro-algae process. One of the challenges is to analyze the opportunities offered by its integration within the bio-based production scheme [40] and how the use of CO2 and wastewater streams to grow the microalgae can combine improved economics, lower GHG emissions and improved water and waste management. There are various other possibilities of integration of CO2 utilization within bio-economy value chain to make a step-forward to an innovative, sustainable and inclusive bio-economy. They were discussed elsewhere [5,31] and will be thus only briefly remarked here. It should be pointed, however, that there are other possibilities of use of CO2 in chemical production, for example to produce polycarbonate, but which do not well integrate within the scheme of biorefineries. This is a fast evolving area of research, although few authors have analyzed in depth the various possibilities of integration of CO2 use within biorefineries. A key element, however, is the availability of renewable H2 (rH2), e.g. not using fossil fuels for the production (we exclude here nuclear energy mainly due to the low social acceptance). This is a determining element to enable CO2 reduction routes, but also relevant in several paths to produce chemicals and especially fuels from biomass. There are different possible routes: - bio-processes based on enzymes or bacteria, - solar thermal or using semiconductors, - advanced electrolysis coupled with renewable electrical energy, - catalytic either in gas or liquid phase using waste or byproducts streams from biomass transformation, - microbial electrolysis. It is out of the scope to discuss and compare here these routes. It should be remarked, however, that often data are missing for a true comparison and economic estimation, even if preliminary. From an applicative perspective, electrolysis using PEM (polymer electrolyte membrane) electrolyzers and aqueous phase reforming (APR) of waste streams are the only technologies exploitable today. The first can be competitive only when the cost of electrical energy is lower than about 5ȼ/kW, while the second requires developing still more stable and productive catalysts for real feeds rather than model compounds [41–46]. In both cases, however, H2 is produced under pressure (>30 bar), while almost other methods produce H2 at atmospheric pressure. Recompression of H2 to typical conditions of use (for CO2 reduction or biomass hydrogenation) makes further costly the process. In addition, productivities in most of the cases are still rather low. In bio-hydrogen, for example, one of the best enzymatic hydrogen production rates reported [47] in optimized conditions from mixed sugars was 54 mmo l H 2 /(L h). In photocatalysis, using sugars as sacrificial alcohols, productivities are lower or comparable at the best [48]. In APR reaction, an estimated productivity [49] is four to five times higher than that of enzymatic production. Virent BioForming process (DoE Working Group) for H2 production by APR claims a productivity of around 5–10 mo l H 2 /(L . h), thus about two order of magnitude higher than best enzymatic bio-H2 production rate, although at least one order of magnitude lower than current productivity in H2 production by methane steam reforming. Costs of H2 production from non-fossil-fuels are still at least twice higher than those from fossil-fuels, except when rather cheap electrical energy is available [50]. 6 Methanol: at the crossover of new energy-chemistry nexus Methanol is at the crossover of the new energy-chemistry nexus, because shows unique characteristics of flexibility, one of the characterizing requirements for the future energy-chemistry scenario. Methanol can be used both as (1) chemical and raw material for large-volume chemicals, and (2) fuel, both as blending component or to produce a range of other components for fuels. It may be produced both from (i) fossil fuels (methane, and from coal, the latter in rapid expansion in China) and (ii) non-fossil-fuel sources (residue/biomass/renewable + CO2). Methanol is thus one of the most important and versatile platform chemicals for chemical industry, but also a key element in the transformation to a sustainable energy future, for example to trade RE on world scale [50]. There are different pushes to promote methanol larger use: (i) to exploit coal in Asian region, (ii) to promote use of renewables in Europe, and (iii) to utilize shale gas in a more flexible way in United States. Methanol is one of the chemicals/fuels with the largest growing rate in the last decade, with its demand increasing, from about 35 MMT (million metric tons) in 2005 to over 70 MMT in 2015, nearly doubling the CAGR (compound annual growth rate) in the last 5 years with respect to the average in the decade before. A significant increase is shown by use to produce - formaldehyde, driven from expansion in polymers and resins particular in Asian market, - olefins (MTO/MPT processes) in the last few years, particularly in China, - DME (also especially in China), - gasoline/fuel/biodiesel (especially in Europe). An overview of the paths to produce methanol as well of the main routes to produce fuels and chemicals from methanol is reported in Fig. 2 which evidences how methanol it is at the crossroad between past and future, being a key element to allow an efficient transition to sustainable energy and chemistry. There is no other equivalent chemical with a so large range of possibilities of production from fossil and non-fossil sources and a so wide range of applications, from energy to chemical area, including a key role to allow an efficient transition to a low-carbon economy. In the area of energy and energy carriers (fuels), we may distinguish different paths of utilization of methanol: (1) As direct energy carrier (gas turbines, heat generation, DMFC) (2) As component of the fuel mix (direct blending in gasoline or diesel) (3) As energy storage/transport chemical (via CO2/rH2 conversion) (4) As raw material to produce other energy carriers (DME, gasoline by MTG) (5) As co-reactant to produce components of fuel mix (MTBE, TAME, biodiesel) Methanol and DME are key intermediate to produce liquid fuels (gasoline, kero and gasoil) by different routes which are currently investigated by many companies. DME can be synthetized either directly from syngas, or in a two-step process via methanol. The latter is the most used industrially. The methanol dehydration reaction to DME is catalyzed by acidic compounds such as γ-alumina, silica-alumina, zeolites (HZSM-5, NaHZSM-5, HY, Ferrierite) or meso-porous materials (MCM and SAPO families), or ZrO2. The main factors influencing the activity and selectivity are the acidic sites strength and the structural characteristics (e.g. pore size distribution). High acidity strength is undesirable, because it is further catalyzing the DME conversion to hydrocarbons. Therefore, the sites with medium acidity insure better performances. For this reason, creation of mesoporosity to improve diffusivity may enhance also deactivation, without a precise control of the type of acid sites created in the process. Methanol can be thus considered the ideal energy vector to guarantee a smooth and effective transition from the actual, oil-centric, energy system to the new, more sustainable energy future. Methanol use in chemical production is also of increasing relevance for the role of methanol as ideal transitional molecule between - the current use of fossil fuels, - the extended use of fossil fuels (coal and unconventional fossil fuels, and CO2 deriving from fossil fuels), - the use of new “renewable” raw materials (biomass and CO2, when the latter derives from biomass processes) and energy, including to introduce RE in the chemical industry and to trade on large scale RE. It may be distinguished different branches for chemical use of methanol: (i) the acetic acid branch, e.g. the production of acetic acid (and derivate) by carbonylation of methanol, (ii) the formaldehyde branch and (iii) the DME and olefin branch. DME can be converted (it is the intermediate when starting from methanol) in the MTO and derived (MTP) processes. Propylene (MPT) is of particular interest recently, due to shortage consequently to shift from naphtha to ethane in steam crackers. Adapting the MTO process (e.g. the catalyst), aromatics can be targets (MTA) as main product. MTO and analogous processes, including MTA, are emerging methanol demand segment. Olefin production from methanol/DME is fast growing particularly in China, with several plants completed or advanced stage of construction for a total capacity of over 18 MMT. Few of these are based on 2nd general processes which integrate a downstream stage to crack ≥C4 hydrocarbons to lighter one. An example is the second generation DMTO process developed by DICP (China) [51]. MTO process is characterized by a high selectivity and yield to light olefins, particularly on zeolite catalysts such as SAPO-34 giving >90% selectivity to C2–C4 olefins. Fast deactivation and exothermicity requires the use of a fluid bed reactor with continuous regeneration. A turbulent fluidized bed reactor offers operational advantages over the bubbling and fast fluidized bed due to the excellent catalyst−gas contact, high mass transfer efficiency, and large solids holdup. 7 The role of chemistry in this new scenario Chemistry will thus play a significant role in the arena of energy storage and energy chain, although the role is often hidden. Fig. 3 gives a schematic representation of this energy chain that in reality is a complex energy system with many interactions. There is a set of primary energy resources, processes and technologies for conversion, transport, storage and final uses of energy. Chemistry has a main role in many of the critical components of this energy chain, as schematically shown in Fig. 3 in terms of key elements to realize a sustainable energy production and use. We may further distinguish three main elements to realize a sustainable energy: (i) conservation, (ii) rational use of fossil fuels, and (iii) use of renewable sources. We have excluded here the use of nuclear energy being progressively banned in several countries. Chemistry is the strategic core discipline for the conversion processes based on solar energy, but it is indispensable to save energy in both production and use. Catalysis, in particular heterogeneous catalysis, is a key factor to develop novel or improved energy-saving processes and to reduce the resource intensity as well the impact on the environment. Improved nanomaterial are critical for energy saving and to enable more energy-efficient processes. Electrical energy storage in Li ion or redox flow batteries requires to understand many chemical aspects at the basis of a rational design of functional electrodes and storage materials. Next generation clean and energy-efficient technologies will emerge from new materials made available by emerging nanoscience and nanotechnologies [52]. Examples are materials that (i) maintain performances at extreme conditions, (ii) self-heal in harsh environments, (iii) lighter that steel but also stronger, (iv) convert sunlight or produce light more efficiently, (v) allow to save energy in separation processes, (vi) permit higher energy density storage, etc. The development in nanotechnology over the last decades allowed passing now from the lab scale to the commercial application, and we thus expect a boost in new materials with properties optimized to sustainable energy technology requirements. Addressing the energy challenge thus require a multidisciplinary approach and the identification of clear targets and R&D objectives, some of which are briefly summarized below according to the three main sectors cited before [1a]: – Energy saving e.g. reduce the energy and raw materials consumption by introducing new processes, materials and technologies. For example: (i) new more selective processes and/or that operate with lower energy consumption, (ii) new materials (for example, foams for improved thermal isolation, new materials to reduce car consumption – lighter materials substituting steel, nanostructured paints to increase the vehicle aerodynamic, tires with reduced friction, etc., solid-state lighting, e.g. LEDs, etc.), (iii) new technologies (for example, new materials to recover electrical energy from waste low-temperature streams or save energy in the conditioning of buildings). We may classify in this class also fuel cells, particularly low temperature proton exchange membrane fuel cells, also known as polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cells, for mobile applications (cars, etc.), and high temperature solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) for residential applications. The main objective of fuel cells, in fact, is to improve the efficiency in chemical to electrical energy. – Sustainable use of fossil fuels, with the introduction of new processes and technologies, which together with a further reduction of the impact of current refineries (only about half of the petroleum entering in a refinery is converted to valuable products, the remaining is used for the energy needs of refinery), allow the valorization in a sustainable approach of not- or less-conventional fossil fuels: (i) coal (for example, coal combustion integrated with emissions purification and CO2 sequestration/use; coal to liquid–CTL), (ii) shale gas and strained natural gas (NG), e.g. the large amounts of NG which are in remote areas and for which transport by pipelines or liquefaction is not convenient (for example, by converting to liquid fuels–GTL), (iii) extra-heavy oils, tar sand or oil shale, bitumen etc. for example developing new energy-effective membranes for O2 separation, which is used then for the combustion of these fractions – the air separation method by distillation used currently is very energy-intensive). – Use of RE resources, first of all solar energy by developing new (nanostructured) materials able to more efficiently harvest and convert light to electrical energy and in long-term to use solar energy to produce solar fuels. Within this area falls also that related to the use of biomass and in general to the development of a bio-based (energy efficient) economy [53]. A critical aspect for electrical energy is the difficult storage of electrons, and therefore this area includes the intense developments related to the improvement of e− storage (Li batteries, supercapacitors, etc.) [17,52,54]. In general, storage and transport (out of the grid) of the electrical energy is the critical issue which determines the need of developing suitable energy vectors, where chemistry plays a central role. Other forms of RE depend also in one or more aspects from the improved materials, which can be developed by chemistry. For example, rotor blade reinforced with carbon nanotubes allow to improve the performances of wind turbines. 8 Nanomaterials for a sustainable energy The development of novel and/or improved materials is a key element to realize the targets cited before, and a significant push has been given to this sector from the development of nanotechnologies. Nanomaterials are defined those which properties stem from their nanoscale dimensions. This dimension refers to the characteristic dimension of the functional units in the nanometer range. An interesting example showing how novel nanomaterials concepts contributes to develop improved devices and technologies for sustainable energy is given from the analysis of the role of the nano-architecture in the development of advanced electrodes [17,54–58]. There are several key technological areas of the energy sector, which require a better design of the electrode nanostructure to overcome current limits and/or move to new levels of their performances: (i) photo-electrochemical solar cells, (ii) water photoelectrolysis, (iii) photoelectrocatalytic devices for the conversion of CO2 to fuels, (iv) advanced Li-batteries, (v) supercapacitors, (vi) fuel cells, (vii) third generation photovoltaic cells and (viii) nanostructured thermoelectric devices. In all these electrodes, the common problem is how to control/optimize the mass and charge transport (i.e. electronic and ionic mobility), the electron-transfer kinetics in multi-phase boundaries, and the modifications on these processes, which occur upon application of a potential between the electrodes. Therefore, optimization of the performances requires the ability to control a complex reaction environment, where many kinetic aspects simultaneously concur in determining the performances. Many of these controlling aspects are size dependent. Recently, it was recognized that not only the nano-dimension would be relevant, but critical is also the nano-architecture of these materials. In general, there is a design problem related to find the optimal compromise between nanosize, nanoarchitecture, robustness and stability, and performances per unit weight or volume, together with a method of producing the electrode, which is cost-effective and scalable. The concept of hierarchical organized materials is a useful approach to reach the above objectives with the development of a multilevel 3D organization based on a host macrostructure, which allows the right tridimensional organization necessary for a fast mass-transport, for example. On this host macrostructure, a secondary guest micro- and/or nano-scale sub-structure is built in order to take advantage of the properties of nanometer-sized building blocks and micron-sized assemblies. Lithium-ion batteries (LIB) are rechargeable devices in which lithium (Li) ions move from the negative electrode to the positive electrode during discharge, and back when charging [59,60]. Unlike Li primary batteries (which are disposable), Li-ion cells use an intercalated Li compound as the electrode material instead of metallic Li. LIBs are common in consumer electronics, because have the best energy-to-weight ratios, no memory effect, and a slow loss of charge when not in use. Their relevance is increasing for military, electric vehicle, and aerospace applications, but the energy density storage should be further improved. Traditional electrode materials for LIBs are based on micrometer-sized materials which have both mixed electron and ion transport (for Li+), such as (i) layered metal oxides that have high redox potentials, and act as positive electrodes, and (ii) graphitic carbons capable of reversible uptake of Li at low potentials which act as negative electrodes. The use of nanostructured solid-state materials, due to the intimate nanoscale contact, allows not only increasing the power density, but also to enhance Li reversibility and thus life cycle. In fact, the cycle ability of Li+ ion transfer depends on the dimensional stability of the host material during insertion and deinsertion of Li+ ions. Mechanical stress occurs during charge/discharge cycles, causing cracks and finally loss of performances. The necessary breakthrough to increase specific storage capacities relies from one side on the in-depth understanding of the complex interface processes of the charge-carrying chemical species (Li) during discharge and charge of the battery, and from the other side on the development of synthetic procedures to prepare the nano-designed electrodes. Developing oriented nanostructures on a nanoscale is one of the directions of research actively explored. There are many advanced methods to prepare tailored hierarchical organized structures for electrodes. Ordered metal nanostructures with hierarchical porosity (macropores in combination with micro- or mesopores) can be prepared using colloidal crystals (or artificial opals), i.e. an ordered array of silica or polymer microspheres, as template on which the metal particles are deposited. By careful removal of the template material, it may be then obtained an ordered metal nanostructure. The extension of the concept of template synthesis for tailored nanomaterials is the synthesis of replica mesostructures by nanocasting. Nanocasting, using highly ordered mesoporous silica as a template, has brought forward incredible possibilities in preparation of novel mesostructured materials, and has led to a great number of ordered nanowire arrays with (i) small diameter (<10 nm), (ii) large surface areas (up to 2500 m2/g) and uniform mesopores (1.5–10 nm) diameter, (iii) tunable 2D or 3D mesostructures, (iv) controlled morphology such as spheres, rods, films, and monoliths and (v) different components including carbons, metals, metal oxides and metal sulfides. The method has been initially used in the preparation of ordered mesoporous carbon materials [61,62]. Recent breakthroughs in the preparation of porous materials have resulted in the development of methods for the preparation of mesoporous carbon materials with extremely high surface areas and ordered mesostructures. Current syntheses can be categorized as either hard-template or soft-template methods, but the synthesis essentially involves C precursor infiltration in the template pores, its carbonization, and subsequent template removal. Consecutive surface functionalization of the carbon materials obtained, for a further optimization of their characteristics is possible. The carbon replica material can be then also the template for other replica materials. The nanocasting method can be used for preparation of a variety of mesostructured and mesoporous materials, including mesostructured metal and semiconductor nanowires. Although powerful, the nanocasting method has limits in terms of cost and scale-up. The alternative approach is based on the synthesis of small-size particle units using the various available physico-chemical methods, such as colloidal, sol–gel and micelle methods as well as other wet or gas phase procedures. These nanounits may be then organized in 2D and 3D super-structures by self- or directed-assembling, seeded or field-induced growth, epitaxial growth or other nano-structuring procedures. An interesting area in fast development is also that of assisting the self-assembling (in particular, to avoid a fractal-type growth) by an electrical field. An example of these electrochemical methods is the anodic oxidation. The electrical field created at the interface between the electrode and electrolyte is a powerful factor for orientation of nanostructure growth. There are several other methods to prepare nanotailored materials for energy application, and the above discussion was not finalized to discuss exhaustively the topic, but to give a glimpse of the possibilities. This is a very fast emerging area of chemistry S&T with high relevance to produce new sustainable solutions for energy. 9 Nanocarbons to design advanced energy conversion and storage devices In order to evidence in a more detail the role of nano-tech materials to enable the development of new devices for energy conversion and storage, and to allow the transition to a sustainable energy system, it is useful to briefly discuss the specific case of nanocarbons. Carbon materials play a limited role in a fossil fuel dominated energy scenario, but their importance is increasing progressively to the moving to this new energy scenario and the need of our society for a distributed and transportable high-density energy. Graphite is the mostly used anode materials in the commercialized lithium ion batteries. Activated carbon remains the only active materials for supercapacitors, and carbon black the support for electrocatalysts in fuel cells. All these are energy conversion and storage devices that can be transferred into a solar energy-based future energy scenario, however, their performances are below the requirements for a non-fossil energy based society in which not only cellar phone, laptop or cars but also power station, long-distance transport, lighting and heating needs to be powered. This future energy scenario is the driving force for the current activities in carbon materials research for energy and chemical synthesis application [58,63,64]. The motivations for the choice of carbon are many: carbon is cheaper, abundant, environmental friendly, and carbon with its various bonding states and allotropes allows a derivation of a family of new carbon materials, the basis of the so-called nanocarbon science. These nanocarbon materials are foreseen to play a special role in the future energy scenario that the classical carbon cannot have. Comparing to conventional energy materials, carbon nanomaterials possess unique size-/surface-dependent (e.g., morphology, electrical, optical, and mechanical) properties that allow a step-forward in enhancing the energy-conversion and storage performances. The basic members of the new carbon family are fullerene, graphene, and carbon nanotube (CNTs). Derived from them are carbon quantum dots, nanohorn, nanofiber, nano ribbon, nanocapsulate, nanocage and other nanomorphology. The common advantages of these new carbon materials are their low dimension, specific morphology and the morphology-defined properties. All sp2-hybridization derived nanocarbon are well ordered and possess a long-range ordering, but they differ from classical bulk graphite. The nano-dimension with the specific morphology gives them physical and chemical properties that other classical carbons do not have: high electroconductivity, good thermal conductivity, and outstanding mechanical properties. It is possible to tailor the electronic structure by introducing heteroatoms, to adapt the physical property by controlling the pore structure, and to change the chemical property by introducing functional groups on the surface. In this way it is possible to introduce a level of control in the characteristics of these materials not possible in other systems. Another important characteristic of the new carbon materials is the possibility to design and architecture hybrid or composite materials [18]. An interesting example, with large interest to develop improved systems for producing solar fuels, is given from TiO2-nanocarbons (CNTs, graphene, etc.) hybrids [65,66]. TiO2 nanoparticles deposited over graphene (which acts as electron acceptor) show an enhanced charge separation and improved performances in water photoelectrolysis. Nanocarbon can act also as electron donors, i.e. photosensitizers (carbon quantum dots). The intrinsic properties of TiO2 may also change by this interaction with nanocarbons and the creation of hybrid materials. As a consequence, these hybrid nanomaterials show several potential advantages in photochemical application, due to the different modalities in which nanocarbon can modify the TiO2 properties. Nanocarbons can 1. transfer electrons into the inorganic compound and so act as a photosensitizer in extending the absorption range; 2. accept photoexcited electrons from the inorganic compound, thus separating them from the photoactive holes; 3. conduct away excess heat during the catalytic reaction; 4. act as a template and heat sink to stabilize smaller catalyst particles whose larger specific surface area can convert more reactant molecules; 5. reduce the amount of active catalyst, decrease their weight and improve cyclability and overall lifetime. In most cases, the obtained hybrid or composite materials with hierarchical structure have a strong synergistic effort combining the advantage of the two building blocks. On the other hand, only a careful control in the preparation and nature of the hybrid material allows exploiting these potential characteristics. Another interesting example is that of the carbon–carbon hybrids composed by different type of nanocarbons. For example, zero-, one-, and two-dimensional nanostructured carbon allotropes, i.e., fullerenes, SWCNT and graphenes in combination with electron-donating conjugated molecules are promising building blocks for artificial photosynthesis and solar energy conversion [67]. In porphyrin–fullerene linked dyads, efficient photoinduced electron transfer occurs to yield the charge-separated state in competition with the decay of the excited states to the ground state. Moderate length-spacers between donor (porphyrin) and acceptor (fullerenes) are essential to produce a long-lived charge-separated state efficiently. However, in a solid material or when these dyads are deposited over a surface, intermolecular direct quenching between different dyads dominates the overall performances, if not a highly diluted system is realized. The use of these systems requires thus to create a superstructure which avoids/minimize from one side these effects allowing at the same time a high density of dyads to improve productivity and overall performances. One of the possibilities is to realize supramolecular hybridization of SWCNT with fullerenes [67]. SWCNT can act as both electron-acceptor and -donor in the SWCNT–fullerene composites, and also act as efficient wire on the charge-transporting properties. In this way, devices could be realized having well dispersed linked dyads (minimizing their direct interaction) over a substrate using the SWCNT as backbone and at the same time wire to improve the electrical communication between the dyads and the collecting substrate [67]. These materials are promising to develop new artificial photosynthesis devices and solar cells. A different interesting possibility is the development of advanced Z-schemes for water splitting [68]. One of the main approaches for achieving water splitting using visible light is to apply a two-step photoexcitation mechanism between two different photocatalysts. This process was inspired by natural photosynthesis in green plants and is known as Z-scheme. In two-step systems, the water splitting reaction is broken up into two stages: one for H2 evolution and the other for O2 evolution; these are combined by using a shuttle redox couple (Red/Ox, for example the I3 −/I− pair) in the solution. Over a H2 evolution photocatalyst, the photoexcited electrons reduce water to H2 and holes in the valence band oxidize the reductant (Red) to an oxidant (Ox). The oxidant is reduced back to the reductant by photoexcited electrons generated over an O2 evolution photocatalyst, where the holes oxidize water to O2. This system lowers the energy required for photocatalysis, allowing visible light to be utilized more efficiently than in conventional water-splitting systems. The use of solutions has a number of practical problems to realize solar cells (sealing, light scattering, etc.). A recent interesting development is based the use of photoreduced graphene oxide as a solid electron mediator for water splitting in the Z-scheme photocatalysis system [69]. The graphene sheet can shuttle photogenerated electrons from an O2-evolving photocatalyst (BiVO4) to a H2-evolving photocatalyst (Ru/SrTiO3:Rh), triplicating the consumption of electron–hole pairs in the water splitting reaction under visible-light irradiation. These examples show the potential to use advanced hybrid nanoarchitectures based on nanocarbons for producing solar fuels. 10 Exploiting solar energy Enabling the new proposed sustainable energy scenario requires also improving the current performances of solar cells by a better design of nanostructure to optimize the light harvesting and efficiency in the conversion to electrical energy at cost-competitive conditions. In fact, current new generation photovoltaic (PV) cell (multi-junction devices) already allow to obtain high conversion yields up to 40%, but the costs are too high and commercially solar cells (based on crystalline or amorphous Si) ensure 12%–18% yields. There are also some other constrains in silicon solar panels related to their architectural integration. They are dark in color, rigid and should be positioned at 45° to the incidence of sunlight for optimum efficiency. The maximum theoretical efficiency of a single solar cell is limited to 33%, but this limit could be overcome using multiple cells, with varying band gaps, in a serial (tandem) arrangement. The first generation of PV cells was based upon silicon wafers, in which material costs accounted for over 70% of the total cost, and overall efficiency was of around 20%. Thin-film techniques were used in the second generation of PV cells. The primary benefit is a reduction in production costs at the expenses of efficiency limited to between 5% and 10%. So-called third generation PV cells seek to achieve efficiencies greater than 50% [70,71], with the hope of approaching the thermodynamic limit of 93%, without radically changing the manufacturing process of second-generation cells. If manufacturing costs can be kept comparable to those of thin film cells, and efficiency greatly improved, then the overall cost per kWh can be dramatically decreased. The operation principle of a PV cell is apparently simple. When a photon with energy higher than the band gap of absorber material hits a p–n junction, it creates an electron hole pair and due to the inbuilt electric field, photo-produced carriers are transported to the electrodes. Thus for making a solar cell, the basic requirements are an absorber material and a junction with an electric field that assists the transport of the photo-generated carriers to the electrodes. There is also a probability that photo-generated carriers can recombine before reaching the electrodes. Therefore, the charge separation time of photo generated carriers must be smaller than the minority carrier lifetime for crystalline and polycrystalline solar cells. The energy associated to photons greater than the energy band gap of silicon is converted into heat. This is one of the reasons of the limit in the efficiency. In tandem solar cells [72], already used for manufacturing amorphous silicon solar cells and III–V-based high efficiency concentrator solar cells, materials with different band-gaps are used to improve this efficiency. In multiple-junction solar cells, several different materials are used to reach efficiencies up to 40%–42%, but with exponentially increasing costs. A different approach is based on the use of nanostructures to build new highly efficient solar cells, based on the following concept: - Hot carriers generated by absorbing photons of energy more than the energy band gap can be employed to generate additional current and or voltage. - Energy states in the energy band gap can be used to trap carriers generated from photon of energy lower than the energy band gap. Various approaches based on one-, two-, and three-dimensional nanostructures (quantum dots and semiconductor nanocrystals) are currently investigated [73]. For example, well-ordered arrays of nanopillars in Si, to be used as the inorganic semiconductor-phase in bulk-heterojunction PV cells, could be prepared by nanocasting. The method could be extended to develop nanocrystals-based tandem solar cells, based also on other semiconductors. It was also shown recently that it is also possible to fabricate highly ordered nanopillar-based solar-cell modules on flexible substrates using techniques compatible with roll-to-roll processing, which potentially brings down costs [74]. It is thus an area in fast expansion, which is driven from the increasing knowledge in nanotechnology and chemistry of nanomaterials. A different approach in third-generation solar cells is that of the dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs, often indicated as Grätzel-type cells) [75] and of organic and conductive polymers, in particular to develop ultra-low-cost solar cells. DSSCs utilize three main components to perform photo-electro conversion: a metal oxide semiconductor (TiO2), dye and an electrolyte. A dye is used to create electron hole pairs and other two materials transport these photogenerated charge carriers to the electrodes. The best efficiency reported is about 11%–12%, and still a number of technical problems have to be solved, in terms of electrolyte, stability, sealing, etc. However, there are a number of aspects making attracting these materials, besides the potential to decrease the cost of production: lightness, transparency and flexibility, possibility to deposit on any surface (including fabrics), possibility to produce in different colors, varying the chemical nature of the dye sensitizer. These PV devices thus have high potential in terms of adaptability and integration with the environment and architecture, for example, the creation of PV windows or roofs in historic centers. 11 Exploiting methane Availability and low cost of shale-gas is another of the elements which determine the future energy and chemistry scenario, although it is still under discussion which effective impact will have [1b,76,77]. Natural gas (methane) catalytic conversion to liquid fuels or chemicals is an active research line. Pearl GTL (gas-to-liquid) (Shell, Qatar) is an example of large plant (140.000 barrels a day) to convert methane to middle distillate, based on the use of cobalt-based catalysts for Fisher-Tropsch reaction. Around one third of natural gas resources (NG) are defined as stranded, e.g. not usable because too far to be introduced in NG pipeline network or because they cannot be transported by liquefaction. GTL is one possibility to convert these resources to a liquid fuel (diesel) for the market. Notwithstanding the high expectation, this solution has not be spread over the specific Qatar situation, due to the need to have very large gas fields, the high costs of operation and other issues. There is thus still the need to develop novel catalytic solutions able to produce liquid fuels, may be alternative to middle distillate, which apply to small-medium size stranded gas fields. The need to produce syngas from NG is a significant part of the cost in GTL process, around one third of the total cost. Therefore, the solution for small-middle scale conversion of methane is its direct conversion (e.g. without passing from syngas), to produce directly fuels such as methanol, DME (dimethylether), aromatics. There is a large attempt to develop novel catalysts to develop these novel direct routes for the selective conversion of methane, as summarized in Fig. 4 . On the other hand, the possibility to reduce energy use and costs of the production of syngas, for example by introduction of new process schemes based on the integration of membranes, is a valuable option particularly for small-medium size applications [78]. Although some of the routes summarized in Fig. 4 are known from several years (oxidative coupling of methane, OCM, for example), the changing landscape in methane cost due to availability of shale gas, the competiveness push to develop new solutions to enter into a highly competitive market (particularly for venture capital companies) and novel scientific advances in both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts, and bio-catalysts as well, have largely stimulate both scientific and industrial interest in this area [79–81]. For example, a number of companies (for example, Chevron, Exxon Mobil, Shell, Honeywell–UOP, etc.) are actively investigating the possibility to develop a commercially viable gas-to-ethylene process. Various other companies are looking to the other processes indicated in Fig. 4. Various novel companies are exploring unconventional solutions to address this challenging area, like as examples: (i) Siluria Technologies that is using virus-based templates to guide the growth of nanowire inorganic catalysts for OCM reaction; (ii) Synfuels that is developing a process in which methane is transformed to acetylene in a pyrolysis reactor and then in a liquid phase hydrogenation acetylene is converted to ethylene; (iii) Calysta Energy Inc. that is developing novel biocatalytic routes of methane fermentation to produce various chemicals, including lactic acid (building block for NatureWorks Ingeo™ lactide intermediates and polymers used in consumer and industrial products worldwide). Also the traditional area of syngas production (a raising market expected to grow at a CAGR of 8.7%, over the next 5 years to reach 117,400 MW thermal by 2018) characterized by many technology licensors (Air Liquide, Haldor Topsoe, Air Products & Chemicals, KBR, Siemens, MHI and Foster Wheeler among several others), shows many new attracting directions of development (listed in Fig. 4) to improve energy efficiency of the process. There is a return of interest, both at academic and industrial level, on OCM reaction. The alternative route via halomethane has some practical interest, but also severe limitations for exploitation, due to the difficulties and safety aspects related to the use of large amounts of halogen compounds [80,82]. The route of methane pyrolysis and hydrogenation has also various limits in exploitation, although actively pushed from the company Synfuels. Catalytic methane decomposition is mainly dedicated to specific niche applications. The presence of mixed homogeneous-heterogeneous reactions in OCM is still a main issue that determines not only severe problems in scale-up of traditional reactors, but also in approaching the reaction in microreactors. Attempts to combine the exothermic OCM reaction with endothermic steam reforming (SR) reaction appear conceptually a very valid option to operate in autothermal conditions and thus improve energy efficiency of the whole process. However, the implementation of this concept still shows severe technical issues. Another emerging route is related to the use of non-thermal plasma, in the various different possible options to generate the plasma [83]. This approach presents a conceptual change of paradigm, from the issue of methane activation (or simultaneous CO2 and/or H2O activation) to the control of selectivity in the pathway of catalytic further conversion. In fact, the plasma is able to activate in very mild conditions (close to room temperature) these molecules and generate very active (mainly radical-type) species. The challenge is thus to design specific catalysts able to operate with these reactive species (without quenching them) and convert them (selectively) to the target products. Up to now, catalysts and catalyst-plasma (hybrid plasma) interaction has been not enough considered from these perspectives, which open very interesting possibilities to move plasma-based process from mainly lab-scale to industrialization. The use of metal transition in zeolites (Zn, Cu, Ga, etc.) is opening new rather interesting possibilities for new gas and liquid phase transformations of methane to products such as methanol, olefins etc. [84–86]. However, productivity is a main issue and still a clear route to overcome this problem has not been identified. In addition, still different reaction conditions and temperatures are necessary to close the catalytic cycle, although modern reactor technologies can solve this issue. Thus, enhance productivity is the key aspect to be solved. There are also various approaches reported in literature using alternative oxidants that O2 (H2O2, N2O, etc.) [87]. However, in most of the latter cases, even the basic economic conditions to explore industrial feasibility are not present. The same is valid for some “dream” reactions, such as the direct conversion of CH4 and CO2 to acetic acid on metal-containing zeolites [88]. Main environmental and technical limits also hinder exploitability of approaches using fuming sulfuric acid (Periana-type catalysts) or superacids such AlBr3–HBr. Studies continue in this directly also very recently, although not addressing the effective key limits for exploitability of these routes. Biocatalytic routes is one of the growing area with very interesting perspectives, also taking into account the significant progresses made in the reaction mechanism [89]. The key for exploitability is to enhance productivity. The combination with solid (photo)catalysts to enhance the rate of reaction and/or close the cycle is one of the (slowly) emerging areas, but that likely will play a critical role in the future, perhaps in combination with suitable “vector molecules” that can enhance methane solubility in aqueous media. The use of solar energy, to supply the heat necessary in endothermic reactions (such as methane reforming) or to induce redox changes in oxides to perform thermochemical cycles for converting methane is a potentially interesting route, but also suffering of severe limits in moving from pilot units to exploitation [90,91]. An emerging possibility is instead to use molten salts as heat-transfer and storage medium [92]. This valuable route will likely find application in a near future. Similar, the integration of membrane in the process schemes to: - produce syngas from methane, - control methane partial oxidation, - improve H2 recovery, is an emerging routes, that will soon pass from pilot to exploitation phase. It may be briefly mentioned that chemical looping [93] also show increasing interest as alternative solution, even though cost is still high. Dry reforming of methane, stimulated from the idea of converting two greenhouse gases (CH4 and CO2) to useful products (syngas), has attracted a very intense research interest in the last years [94,95]. There are some possibilities of industrialization, but in general, other methane conversion routes are preferable from the energy perspective. In specific cases, such as the conversion of biogas containing a mixture of methane and carbon dioxide, this could be a valuable option. It is necessary to turn the perspective of approaching this reaction, and thus related catalysts needs. The use of non-thermal plasma is one of the interesting possibilities, because allow in particular to develop energy-efficient processes on small-medium scale, well suited for applications such as in converting biogas. Biogas, for the possibility to utilize waste resources, is one of the key elements shaping the future of RE [96]. Actual forecast are of a rapid extension of digestors and biogas production that will require the possibility to store in the form of liquid fuels some of the energy produced. Biogas transformation routes are thus one of the emerging routes. In addition to non-thermal plasma, the solar-assisted dry reforming is another valuable option, especially when solar heat is stored in the form of molten salts. These two emerging routes require a new catalyst design with respect to those actually available. In conclusions, there are many progresses in methane direct and indirect conversion routes, stimulated from the (i) availability of NG resources, which cannot be exploited via conventional pipeline or liquefaction/regasification routes, and (ii) break down of parity between NG and oil, making thus methane an interesting source also to produce chemicals. There are some emerging and converging routes, as highlighted above, and some of the options will likely be industrialized in a near future. However, it is necessary to better driven the scientific progresses in this area with a clear identification of the key issues. 12 Conclusions The brief discussion presented here cannot be exhaustive of the complex topic of the future of energy and chemistry, the change of their nexus, the emerging new needs in terms of materials and technologies to make possible and sustainable this changeover. We have thus provided only a glimpse about the future vision of a sustainable energy-chemistry system, the key enabling technologies and some examples of the role of nanotechnology and chemistry in developing them. As indicated, this perspective paper is not intended to be a review on this area, being too broad, but only a (largely personal) vision of the future. References are thus limited as well a detailed discussion of pro/con ideas about this future. The aim is to outline the evolving scenario, and some of the key topics to enable this transition, as the basis to remark the role which may be played from JEC to enable this future. The topics discussed in this perspective paper are part of the strategic elements around which the journal aims to growth, and which put JEC at the crossover of the future model of sustainable energy and chemical production. We could further stress the concept that chemistry, catalysis and chemical engineering had, and will continue to play, a pivotal role in enabling societal needs of energy, in terms of amount and quality of the products, but also of protection of the environment from their use. Energy-chemistry nexus is changing and understanding this change is the basis to develop more focused R&D to enable this sustainable future. We have to remark that several aspects were not included, or very limited discussed, for conciseness. Between these we have at least to cite the role of catalysis in both enabling the use of biomass, and in developing new energy-saving processes for a low-carbon economy. Catalysis and chemistry also plays a role in mitigating the impact on environment of the production and use of energy, for example in reducing pollutant emissions from industrial processes and cars. Enabling a sustainable energy future presents many great challenges, for example related to substitute fossil fuels, allow the large use of renewable as well as alternative energy sources, provide energy security and reliability of the grid and energy net, etc. In many of these challenges, chemistry operates in synergy with other branches of science and technology to make possible the necessary progress. Chemistry is thus a strategic science and technology for solving the energy challenge, providing tailored structural and functional materials, processes and technologies for energy saving, for a better and more efficient use of natural resources by diversification of those actual in use, and for the use of RE. This will require also improving the educational effort in training chemists for this interdisciplinary approach needed to provide creative and scalable solutions to the energy issues. coredata.dc:description: The changing energy-chemistry nexus is discussed in this perspective paper about the future of sustainable energy and chemical production to identify the priorities and open issues on which focus research and development. Topics discussed regard (i) the new sustainable energy scenario, (ii) the role of energy storage (from smart grids to chemical storage of energy), (iii) the outlooks and role of solar (bio)refineries and solar fuels, (iv) how to integrate bio- and solar-refineries to move to new economy, (v) the role of methanol at the crossover of new energy-chemistry nexus, (vi) the role of chemistry in this new scenario, (vii) the role of nanomaterials for a sustainable energy, (viii) the use of nanocarbons to design advanced energy conversion and storage devices, and (ix) possibilities and routes to exploit solar energy and methane (shale gas). The contribution provides a glimpse of the emerging directions and routes with some elements about their possible role in the future scenario, but does not provide a detailed analysis of the state of the art in these directions.
